Although many of the pathetic sentimenta in the closing paragraph are mere rhetorical τόποι,1 he has, nevertheless, succeeded in creating an indelible impression of genuine sorrow, affection, and deep sincerity. .

We, therefore, conclude that the Agricola of Tacitus is exactly what its author says it was —a eulopistic biography, constructed, as we have seen, on fairly orthodox rhetorical lines, more particularly in accord with the detailed rules governing the βασιλικὸς λόγος, preserved in Menandcr’s περὶ ἐπιδεικτικῶν, which, though of a late date, merely reflecte orthodox, scholastic traditions. But these, in their sub- stance, far autedate the time of Tacitus himself.
